title: 107_s1045
content: The Act may be cited as the "NOAA Chesapeake Bay Office Reauthorization Act of 2001". This Act establishes the Chesapeake Bay Office. The NOAA Chesapeake Bay Office Reauthorization Act of 2001 amends the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Authorization Act of 1992 to appoint a Director with knowledge of Chesapeake Bay research or resource management. It also aims to facilitate coordination of programs within the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Chesapeake Bay units of the National Estuarine Research Reserve System, Chesapeake Bay Regional Sea Grant Programs, and Cooperative Oxford Lab conduct various programs and activities related to coastal and estuarine research, fisheries research, data management, remote sensing, coastal management, habitat conservation, restoration, and atmospheric deposition. The Oxford Laboratory of the National Ocean Service focuses on nonindigenous species, marine species pathology, human pathogens in marine environments, and ecosystems health. Amendments to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Authorization Act of 1992 include a requirement for an action plan with recommended research, monitoring, and data collection activities. Amendments to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Authorization Act of 1992 require proposals for continuing and new activities in the Chesapeake Bay, integrating them with partners in the Chesapeake Bay Program to meet agreements. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Authorization Act of 1992 is amended to include a new section 307A for a Multiple Species Management Strategy in the Chesapeake Bay. The Director of the Chesapeake Bay Office will conduct a 5-year study with the scientific community to understand living resources in the Chesapeake Bay ecosystem and develop a multiple species management strategy. The study will focus on determining the status and trends of fish and shellfish in the estuary and evaluating interactions among them. The Director of the Chesapeake Bay Office will conduct a 5-year study with the scientific community to evaluate interactions among fish and shellfish in the Chesapeake Bay ecosystem and recommend management actions for a healthy ecosystem. The Chesapeake Bay Fishery and Habitat Restoration Small Grants Program is established under SEC. 307B. It aims to support restoration efforts in the Chesapeake Bay ecosystem. The Director of the Chesapeake Bay Office, in cooperation with the Chesapeake Executive Council, will implement a small grants program for fishery and habitat restoration in the Chesapeake Bay watershed. Grants will cover up to 75% of project costs for eligible entities working on restoration projects. The small grants program for fishery and habitat restoration in the Chesapeake Bay watershed includes projects such as improving fish passageways, creating reefs, restoring wetlands, producing oysters, and identifying contaminated habitats. Eligible entities for grants include government entities in the Chesapeake Bay watershed and the District of Columbia. The small grants program for fishery and habitat restoration in the Chesapeake Bay watershed includes projects like improving fish passageways, creating reefs, restoring wetlands, producing oysters, and identifying contaminated habitats. Eligible entities for grants include organizations in the watershed described in section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Director may prescribe additional requirements as needed for the program. "SEC. 307C. COASTAL PREDICTION CENTER." The Director of the Chesapeake Bay Office will establish a coastal prediction center within a year to gather, analyze, and organize coastal data for policymakers and resource managers. The coastal prediction center will develop an Internet-based information system for integrating, interpreting, and disseminating coastal information and predictions related to climate, land use, pollution, environmental quality, ecosystem health, aquatic resources, habitat conditions, weather, tides, currents, and circulation in the Chesapeake Bay. The Director of the coastal prediction center may enter agreements with other entities to provide data, information, and support related to activities of the center, as well as grants for the collection and publication of information products. SEC. 4. ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Authorization Act of 1992 is amended to include a new section 307D for an Environmental Education Pilot Program. The Chesapeake Bay Environmental Education Program will be established to improve understanding of the ecosystem for students and teachers. Grants will be provided to not-for-profit institutions for educational programs based on their experience in environmental education. The Chesapeake Bay Environmental Education Program offers grants for education and training programs on the Chesapeake Bay watershed, including classroom education and outdoor experiences. The Chesapeake Bay Environmental Education Program offers grants for education and training programs focused on the Chesapeake Bay watershed. This includes professional development for teachers, dissemination of education materials, field demonstrations, and projects to enhance understanding of environmental issues. The Chesapeake Bay Program offers grants to address environmental problems in the watershed or protect living resources. The Federal share of program costs cannot exceed 75%. The Director conducts annual reviews to assess program quality for continued support. The Director will establish procedures and safety protocols for the program. The program will be effective for four years starting in 2001, with a report due by December 31, 2005 on the program's role for Federal, State, and local governments. The term 'Chesapeake 2000 agreement' refers to the agreement between the United States and the States. The 'Chesapeake 2000 agreement' is the agreement between the United States, Maryland, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and the District of Columbia, entered into on June 28, 2000. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Authorization Act of 1992 is amended to authorize $8,000,000 annually for the Chesapeake Bay Office from 2002 to 2005. Specific amounts are allocated for different programs within the office. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Authorization Act of 1992 authorizes $8,000,000 annually for the Chesapeake Bay Office from 2002 to 2005, with specific allocations for different programs. Section 307C is to be carried out with up to $2,000,000 available, while a conforming amendment removes subsection (e) from the Marine Fisheries Program Authorization Act. SEC. 6. TECHNICAL CORRECTION. Amends Section 307(b) of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Authorization Act of 1992 by changing "Chesapeake Bay Executive Council" to "Chesapeake Executive Council".
